"BUCK" GRACE STARS FOR
HOPKINS IN VICTORY
OVER NAVY

ANNUAL HOMEWOOD CONCERT UNQUALIFIED
SUCCESS

His Thrilling Double Play Prevents Midshipmen from Scoring. Also Scores
Two of His Team's Three Runs.
Knecht Allows But Four Hits.

Every Number Perfectly Rendered. Hawaiian Trio, Jazz Band and
"Johnny Smoker" make
Biggest Hit.

A spectacular one-handed catch
by "Buck" Grace of Niemeyer's
line drive over second base in the
ninth inning of Saturday's game
ended Navy's last chance to score
against the Hopkins balltossers,
who were victorious to the tun eof
three to nothing. After holding the
Midshipmen to two hits, "Andy"
Knecht, who toed the mound for the
home team, allowed the first two
batter in the ninth to hit safely,
placing men on second and third.
It was then that Grace captured
Niemeyer's screaming blow and
touched second, making an unassisted double play. He then threw
to Strouse on third, but the latter

Too much praise. cannot be given
the musical clubs for their excellent performance at the annual
"Homewood Concert" last Saturday. Every number was .perfectly
rendered and was greeted with enthusiastic applause. Although it is
impossible to select any two or
three presentations as having exceptional merit, it is probable that
the Hawaiian Trio, Jazz Band and
"Johnny Smoker" made the greatest hit with the audience which
crowded the C. E. Hall.
The program was opened by the
University Ode, rendered by the
Glee Club. The orchestra then presented the "Overture from the Bohemian Girl," by M. W. Balfe, follnwed by "Humming" as an encore.
The Mandolin Club then played the
"Manhattan Beach March" and
"Hiawatha's Melody of Love."
The fourth number of the program was "On the Road to Mandalay," sung by "Doug. Coulter,
supported by the Glee Club. An an

A. A. BOARD TO BE ELECTED
THURSDAY
Thompson, Engel and Wood Nominated for Presidency of Student Council.

Nominations for the members of
the Athletic Board for 1921-'22
were made at a special meeting on
May 6th. The election will take
place this Thursday at the assembly
hour after the 0. D. K. public initiation. Voting will be on a special
ballot, which will contain the names
of all the candidates. Men nomated for two offices will be given
chance to vgithdraw from one just
before the election takes place.
Following the nominations for
the Athletic Board those for president of the Student Council were
made. The names will be attached
tc the Athletic Board ballot for a
vote next Thursday. Those nominated for Student Council president were J. C. Thompson, G. C.
Engel and R. M. Wood.

(Continued on page 1 col. 4)
TENNIS TEAM FORCED TO
CANCEL TWO MATCHES

The tennis team had to call off
its first two intercollegiate matches
on account of the bad weather pre;'ailing last week. Washington College and Catholic University were
the two teams scheduled.' The final
choice of just who will comprise
the team has had also to be postponed, but Hammond, W. Jacobsen, Duffy and Rowland will prob
ably be the men to uphold Hopkins'
prowess on the courts, although the
playing of Pickford, Miller and
Kesting. promises to'keep the regulars hustling.

MIDDLE ATLANTIC CHAMPIONSHIPS AT HOME-

LACROSSE TEAM FALLS BEFORE STEVENS STICKMEN

Sixteen Colleges, Over Two Hundred
Men Entered. Rutgers or Lafayette Expected to Carry Off
First Honors. ,

Able to Score But Once Against Five
Points Made By Opponents.
Game Played on Muddy Field.

The ninth annual Middle Atlantic
Championships will get under way
at Homewood on Saturday, May 9,
at 2 o'clock. This is the first part
of the big double-header scheduled
for that day, and will be followed
by a lacrosse game between Navy
and Hopkins.
Sixteen colleges, including this
University, which joined last year,
will be represented in the games, in
which over 200 athletes are expected to participate.
The limited quarter at Homewood will not suffice to accommodate such a number, but arrangements are being made to care for
the visitors. A large tent will be
erected near the club-house, which
will serve as a dressing-room and
will be fully equipped with showers,
lockers. and attendants.
Because of the long list of events
and the large number of contestants
it will be necessary to hold the
trials in the morning at 9:30. All
of the finals will be run in the afternoon, starting promptly at 2 o'clock.
Preparations will also be made
to handle the large crowd that will
surely be attracted by the fine program of sports to be crowded into
the one afternoon. If necessary,
the temporary stands .used during
the football season will be set up and
these, together with the concrete
stands, will comfortably accommodate twelve to fifteen thousand
spectators.
(Continued on page 4 col. 3)

The Hopkins lacrosse team journeyed up to Hoboken last Saturday and lost to Stevens Institute by
a 5-to-1 score. The field was very,
wet and muddy, turning the game
into a sliding contest. Hopkins'
stickwork and passing were very
poor. The attack men got but few
good shots at goal. Bauerenschmidt was the only visiting player
able to slip the ball past the Stevens goalkeeper, who played a sensational game throughout.
The outcome of the Stevens game
greatly weakens Hopkins' chances
for the contest with Navy, which
will take place at Homewood this
Saturday. The Stevens aggregation was defeated earlier in the season by Penn State, which was
snowed under by Navy to the tune
of 20 to 2.
LACROSSE SQUAD TO MEET
NAVY
Over 1000 Midshipmen Expected to
Journey to Baltimore. Exciting Contest Promised.

Navy will break one of her long
established traditions 'when she
sends her lacrosse team against the
twelve of Hopkins at Homewood
on May 14.
Prior to this year Navy has been
accustomed to hold her athletic
contests at Annapolis and eAept
for the annual football classic with
Army no athletic team was allowed
to play away from home. The present season marks a departure from
this policy, henceforth each team
will be permitted to engage in one
contest a season on hostile territory
From all reports, however, the
Navy twelve will feel quite at home
this Saturday, for about 1100 midsh:pmen are expected to accompany
the invaders.

KOLLEGE }CLIPPINGS
Oxford-Cambridge Track Meet With
Harvard and Yale Likely.

The probable acceptance by
Harvard and Yale athletic authorities of the suggestion from
Oxford and Cambridge Universities that their track teams come
here for a joint international meet
late in July, was indicated today
by Major Fred W. Moore, graduate treasurer of athletics at Harvard.

THE "HOMEWOOD CONCERT"

Saturday's "Homewood Concrt" is probably the best which has
even been given by a Hopkins Musical Club, even in the balmy days
"before the war." The smoothness
with which the program was carried out and the skill with which
every number was presented prove
that the Musical Clubs have attained a high degree of perfection.
The NEWS-LErrER wishes to take
this opportunity to extend its heartiest congratulations to the officers
and members of the clubs upon this
and past performances. The clubs
have played a big part in the undergraduate life this year and are destined to play an even more important part next year.
It is a pity that more people
could not hear and enjoy the club's
presentation. The C. E. Hall was
crowded and yet probably less than
one-fourth of the student body was
present. Would it not be both
feasible and practical to give a per-

Mr. Dallas, former president of the
Amateur Athletic Union, will act
as chief judge, and will be assisted
by more than sixty track and field
judges and timekeepers.
"Mike" Bowers and his Student
Band will be on hand to enliven the
occasion, and to furnish competition with Navy in the musical line
if the latter so desire.

(Continued from page 1, col. 3)

The local fraternities have agreed
to entertain the visiting athletes
during their stay here, and have also
made all transportation arrangements for the competing colleges.
It is difficult at this date to pick
a winner, the teams are so evenly
matched, but the wise ones venture the assertion that the fight will
finally be narrowed down to Rutgers and Lafayette. Rutgers, who
was victorious last year, seems to
have the advantage by a shade,
judged by her showing in the recent Penn Carnivals.
Just what sort of showing Hopkins will make will depend upon
the form shown within the next few
days. The last two meets do not
show the actual strength of the
track team. The first meet was run
at Swarthmore during a heavy rain,
over a track covered in places by
several inches of water.
In the contest with Delaware
College last week, the track was in
fair shape, but the inclement
weather prevailing that whole week
prevented any systematic training.
Added to this, three of the Black
and Blue's most consistent winners
were suffering from temporary ailments. If the next few days are
bright and warm, however, the
squad will quickly round into shape
and should be in excellent condition for the big event Saturday.
Realizing the importance of having competent and experienced men
to officiate as judges, the management at Homewood has spared no
pains in obtaining the best officials.

A Cheering Section for the Navy Game

May 3rd, 1921.
THE NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University,
Homewood, Baltimore, Md.
Dear Editor—On May 14th, the
United States Naval Academy will
send its lacrosse team to Baltimore
to meet the Black and Blue on
Homewood Field.
Behind its
strong team, which has not been
beaten for two seasons, will come
marching at least one thousand
"rooters, tried and true."
The object of this letter to you
is to urge the student body of the
Hopkins University to get together
a cheering section which will be
able to cope with the Navy backers.
It will take more than players to
win this lacrosse game. This appeal is made as the writer appreciates the tremendous value .of an
organized support of the student
body.
Let us talk up the game and act.
Very truly yours,
Wm. C. SCHMEISSER,
Member of the Lacrosse Committee.

the Navy Team?

April 20, 1921.
Mr. Norman C. Keyes,

the musical clubs for their excellent performance at the annual
"Homewood Concert" last Saturday. Every number was .perfectly
rendered and was greeted with enthusiastic applause. Although it is
impossible to select any two or
three presentations as having exceptional merit, it is probable that
the Hawaiian Trio, Jazz Band and
"Johnny Smoker" made the greatest hit with the audience which
crowded the C. E. Hall.
The program was opened by the
University Ode, rendered by the
Glee Club. The orchestra then presented the "Overture from the Bohemian Girl," by M. W. Balfe, follnwed by "Humming" as an encore.
The Mandolin Club then played the
"Manhattan Beach March" and
"Hiawatha's Melody of Love."

A. A. BOARD TO BE ELECTED
THURSDAY
Thompson, Engel and Wood Nominated for Presidency of Student Council.

Nominations for the members of
the Athletic Board for 1921-'22
were made at a special meeting on
May 6th. The election will take
place this Thursday at the assembly
hour after the 0. D. K. public initiation. Voting will be on a special
ballot, which will contain the names
of all the candidates. Men nomated for two offices will be given
chance to vgithdraw from one just
before the election takes place.
Following the nominations for
the Athletic Board those for president of the Student Council were
made. The names will be attached
tc the Athletic Board ballot for a
vote next Thursday. Those nominated for Student Council president were J. C. Thompson, G. C.
Engel and R. M. Wood.

TENNIS TEAM FORCED TO
CANCEL TWO MATCHES

The tennis team had to call off
its first two intercollegiate matches
on account of the bad weather pre;'ailing last week. Washington College and Catholic University were
the two teams scheduled.' The final
choice of just who will comprise
the team has had also to be postponed, but Hammond, W. Jacobsen, Duffy and Rowland will prob
ably be the men to uphold Hopkins'
prowess on the courts, although the
playing of Pickford, Miller and
Kesting. promises to'keep the regulars hustling.

MIDDLE ATLANTIC CHAMPIONSHIPS AT HOME-

LACROSSE TEAM FALLS BEFORE STEVENS STICKMEN

Sixteen Colleges, Over Two Hundred
Men Entered. Rutgers or Lafayette Expected to Carry Off
First Honors. ,

Able to Score But Once Against Five
Points Made By Opponents.
Game Played on Muddy Field.

The ninth annual Middle Atlantic
Championships will get under way
at Homewood on Saturday, May 9,
at 2 o'clock. This is the first part
of the big double-header scheduled
for that day, and will be followed
by a lacrosse game between Navy
and Hopkins.
Sixteen colleges, including this
University, which joined last year,
will be represented in the games, in
which over 200 athletes are expected to participate.
The limited quarter at Homewood will not suffice to accommodate such a number, but arrangements are being made to care for
the visitors. A large tent will be
erected near the club-house, which
will serve as a dressing-room and
will be fully equipped with showers,
lockers. and attendants.
Because of the long list of events
and the large number of contestants
it will be necessary to hold the
trials in the morning at 9:30. All
of the finals will be run in the afternoon, starting promptly at 2 o'clock.
Preparations will also be made
to handle the large crowd that will
surely be attracted by the fine program of sports to be crowded into
the one afternoon. If necessary,

The Hopkins lacrosse team journeyed up to Hoboken last Saturday and lost to Stevens Institute by
a 5-to-1 score. The field was very,
wet and muddy, turning the game
into a sliding contest. Hopkins'
stickwork and passing were very
poor. The attack men got but few
good shots at goal. Bauerenschmidt was the only visiting player
able to slip the ball past the Stevens goalkeeper, who played a sensational game throughout.
The outcome of the Stevens game
greatly weakens Hopkins' chances
for the contest with Navy, which
will take place at Homewood this
Saturday. The Stevens aggregation was defeated earlier in the season by Penn State, which was
snowed under by Navy to the tune
of 20 to 2.
LACROSSE SQUAD TO MEET
NAVY
Over 1000 Midshipmen Expected to
Journey to Baltimore. Exciting Contest Promised.

Navy will break one of her long
established traditions 'when she
sends her lacrosse team against the
twelve of Hopkins at Homewood
on May 14.
Prior to this year Navy has been
accustomed to hold her athletic
contests at Annapolis and eAept
for the annual football classic with
Army no athletic team was allowed
to play away from home. The present season marks a departure from
this policy, henceforth each team
will be permitted to engage in one
contest a season on hostile territory
From all reports, however, the
Navy twelve will feel quite at home
this Saturday, for about 1100 midsh:pmen are expected to accompany
the invaders.

THE "HOMEWOOD CONCERT"

Saturday's "Homewood Concrt" is probably the best which has
even been given by a Hopkins Musical Club, even in the balmy days
"before the war." The smoothness
with which the program was carried out and the skill with which
every number was presented prove
that the Musical Clubs have attained a high degree of perfection.
The NEWS-LErrER wishes to take
this opportunity to extend its heartiest congratulations to the officers
and members of the clubs upon this
and past performances. The clubs
have played a big part in the undergraduate life this year and are destined to play an even more important part next year.
It is a pity that more people
could not hear and enjoy the club's
presentation. The C. E. Hall was
crowded and yet probably less than
one-fourth of the student body was
present. Would it not be both
feasible and practical to give a per-

Mr. Dallas, former president of the
Amateur Athletic Union, will act
as chief judge, and will be assisted
by more than sixty track and field
judges and timekeepers.
"Mike" Bowers and his Student
Band will be on hand to enliven the
occasion, and to furnish competition with Navy in the musical line
if the latter so desire.

(Continued from page 1, col. 3)

The local fraternities have agreed
to entertain the visiting athletes
during their stay here, and have also
made all transportation arrangements for the competing colleges.
It is difficult at this date to pick
a winner, the teams are so evenly
matched, but the wise ones venture the assertion that the fight will
finally be narrowed down to Rutgers and Lafayette. Rutgers, who
was victorious last year, seems to
have the advantage by a shade,
judged by her showing in the recent Penn Carnivals.
Just what sort of showing Hopkins will make will depend upon
the form shown within the next few
days. The last two meets do not
show the actual strength of the
track team. The first meet was run
at Swarthmore during a heavy rain,
over a track covered in places by
several inches of water.
In the contest with Delaware
College last week, the track was in
fair shape, but the inclement
weather prevailing that whole week
prevented any systematic training.
Added to this, three of the Black
and Blue's most consistent winners
were suffering from temporary ailments. If the next few days are
bright and warm, however, the
squad will quickly round into shape
and should be in excellent condition for the big event Saturday.
Realizing the importance of having competent and experienced men
to officiate as judges, the management at Homewood has spared no
pains in obtaining the best officials.

A Cheering Section for the Navy Game

May 3rd, 1921.
THE NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University,
Homewood, Baltimore, Md.
Dear Editor—On May 14th, the
United States Naval Academy will
send its lacrosse team to Baltimore
to meet the Black and Blue on
Homewood Field.
Behind its
strong team, which has not been
beaten for two seasons, will come
marching at least one thousand
"rooters, tried and true."
The object of this letter to you
is to urge the student body of the
Hopkins University to get together
a cheering section which will be
able to cope with the Navy backers.
It will take more than players to
win this lacrosse game. This appeal is made as the writer appreciates the tremendous value .of an
organized support of the student
body.
Let us talk up the game and act.
Very truly yours,
Wm. C. SCHMEISSER,
Member of the Lacrosse Committee.
May We Call This to the Attention of
the Navy Team?

April 20, 1921.
Mr. Norman C. Keyes,
Manager of Lacrosse,
